ygData.subject: Re: Benchmarks?

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> >  
> >
> In fact some of pole length pairs will be impossible to balance. 
> Certainly poles of equal length are. But how much more complexity do 
> these more difficult DP problems require? ...I'll go check out the 
paper eh.
> 
> Colin.

Tino's paper uses ESP, so it doesn't really address the complexity 
question.  But I have actually done length changing experiments myself 
that haven't been published.  I found I could get to the first 
increment in length without needing incremental evolution in NEAT.  I 
think it took several hundred generations, and actually the network 
was significantly more complex than the usual DPB network (which may 
even have zero hidden nodes).  In fact, you've all probably seen this 
network before.  Can you guess where?

Here's the answer: It's the network in the picture that's been on top 
of the NEAT Users Page for years :)

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html

That's actually a network that can handle poles closer in length.  And 
that's about the complexity level I got every time I tried to solve 
that problem.

ken
